title: Diet
data:
In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, the **diet** of a monster describes which types of things it will eat.

Every monster, including yourself, is restricted to eating only certain [materials](/wiki/Material "Material"). Solid foods that are edible to your starting character are generally classified as [comestibles](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible"), but if you [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a different type of monster, you may find yourself snacking on such things as shirts or wands. Further, many types of monsters have strong innate preferences with regard to meats and vegetable matter.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Your diet](#Your_diet)

- [2 Pets](#Pets)

- [3 Types of diet](#Types_of_diet)

  - [3.1 Omnivore](#Omnivore)
  - [3.2 Carnivore](#Carnivore)
  - [3.3 Herbivore](#Herbivore)
  - [3.4 Metallivore](#Metallivore)
  - [3.5 Inediate](#Inediate)
  - [3.6 Special cases](#Special_cases)
  - [3.7 Internals](#Internals)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)
  - [4.1 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [5 See also](#See_also)

- [6 References](#References)

## Your diet

You, as a monster endowed with free will, are restricted only by your physical capacity to consume. Still, your diet is determined by what you are. Most character types are omnivores, although [monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk") are effectively herbivores, suffering an alignment penalty for eating non-vegetarian food. Being a carnivore or herbivore (or even inediate) does not restrict your ability to eat, but does make the respective food types more delicious.

You are the only creature that can open a [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of food. You can also quaff any form of [liquid nourishment](/wiki/Foodless#Restoring_nutrition "Foodless"), provided you are capable of drinking. When [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a new type of monster, you can eat whatever that monster type can eat, in addition to the usual [comestibles](/wiki/Comestibles "Comestibles"). Note, however, that being *capable* of eating something does not mean that you *should* eat it; eating a dead [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") by mistake has ended many a game, and eating your own race carries the penalties of [cannibalism](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism").

Three [conducts](/wiki/Conducts "Conducts") tracked by the game entail *voluntarily* restricting your diet: vegetarian, vegan, and [foodless](/wiki/Foodless "Foodless").

## Pets

- *See also [Pet#Pet diets](/wiki/Pet#Pet_diets "Pet")*

Most types of monsters eat only when [tame](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness"), i.e., your [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet"); the exceptions are metallivores and other unique diets, which largely avoid safe comestibles. A pet encountering something it is capable of eating will decide whether to eat it according to its dietary preference and its degree of [hunger](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition"), with due care to avoid harmful meals. A pet [cat](/wiki/Cat "Cat"), for example, will eat a banana only when starving. Diet also determines which foods will tame a [domestic animal](/wiki/Domestic_animal "Domestic animal") and which foods a pet considers a [treat](/wiki/Treat "Treat"). Thus it is helpful to be aware of the diets of your [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") or potential pets you want to [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") (that pony wants an apple, not a yucky tripe ration!), besides watching out for monsters that might go after your treasures (a rock mole ate my gold stash!).

Most [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") must continually eat to stave off [starvation](/wiki/Nutrition#Nutrition_and_pets "Nutrition"). Besides a normal state of contentment, a pet has two degrees of hunger. *Hungry* is what a [stethoscope](/wiki/Stethoscope "Stethoscope") and #[chatting](/wiki/Chat "Chat") indicate. *Starving* means the pet "is confused from hunger" or "you feel worried about" it, and implies the pet's maximum hit points are reduced to 25%. Beyond that, it will cease to be your pet, either dying or, if on another level, becoming [hostile](/wiki/Tameness "Tameness").

Pets react differently to various [foods](/wiki/Food "Food") according to how appealing they find it. From best to worst, the grades of food are as follows.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

| Food grade | Internal name                        | Effect                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| ---------- | ------------------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **treat**  | DOGFOOD                              | A delicious [treat](/wiki/Treat "Treat") suitable for [training](/wiki/Apport "Apport").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) Will make pets follow more closely.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4). Pets will "catch" it, which is purely cosmetic.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)                                                                                                          |
| **good**   | CADAVER                              | Will be eaten happily.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| **hungry** | ACCFOOD                              | Will be eaten if hungry,[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) but the pet will seek it out only if starving.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) (Try throwing the food at the pet.) The minimum food grade needed for taming.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) The worst quality food that will to suppress the message "[Foo](/wiki/Foo "Foo") moves only reluctantly."[\[10\]](#cite_note-10) |
| starving   | MANFOOD (ACCFOOD when starving)      | Will be eaten only if starving.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11) Otherwise, the pet wants to apport the food.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| *inedible* | MANFOOD, APPORT, POISON, UNDEF, TABU | Will be left untouched even while the poor creature starves to death.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |

Untame [domestic animals](/wiki/Domestic_animal "Domestic animal") (dogs, cats, and horses) will not eat spontaneously but will react favorably to food you throw at them (apart from eggs, melons, and cream pies that hit their target and splat 99% of the time). If the food is considered grade "hungry" or better, the animal will eat it and become [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame"); this is an easy way to [acquire pets](/wiki/Pet#New_pets "Pet"). Any other [comestible](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible") will not be eaten but will [pacify](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") the animal and remove any [fear](/wiki/Fear "Fear") effects, unless the animal is a domestic u. Only veggy food will pacify domestic horses if not eaten; these items are listed in the "starving herbivores" section of the table below. [\[13\]](#cite_note-13)[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)

Carnivores and herbivores evaluate food in very different ways, tabulated below. The obvious trend to bear in mind is that carnivores prefer meats and herbivores prefer vegetable matter. Omnivores generally apply the more favorable grade out of both.

| Food                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Carnivores | Herbivores |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------- | ---------- |
| [tripe ration](/wiki/Tripe_ration "Tripe ration"), or meat [ring](/wiki/Meat_ring "Meat ring")/[stick](/wiki/Meat_stick "Meat stick")/[ball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball")/[chunk](/wiki/Huge_chunk_of_meat "Huge chunk of meat")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | **treat**  | *inedible* |
| safe [egg](/wiki/Egg "Egg") (do not throw!)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    | **good**   | *inedible* |
| safe [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse"), non-vegan                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                | **good**   | *inedible* |
| safe [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse"), [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             | *inedible* | **good**   |
| [apple](/wiki/Apple "Apple"), [carrot](/wiki/Carrot "Carrot")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  | starving   | **treat**  |
| people food:* [lump of royal jelly](/wiki/Lump_of_royal_jelly "Lump of royal jelly")
* [cream pie](/wiki/Cream_pie "Cream pie") (do not throw!)
* [candy bar](/wiki/Candy_bar "Candy bar")
* [fortune cookie](/wiki/Fortune_cookie "Fortune cookie")
* [pancake](/wiki/Pancake "Pancake")
* [lembas wafer](/wiki/Lembas_wafer "Lembas wafer")
* [food](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration")/[cram](/wiki/Cram_ration "Cram ration")/[K](/wiki/K-ration "K-ration")-/[C](/wiki/C-ration "C-ration")-ration                                                                                          | **hungry** | starving   |
| other [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") [comestibles](/wiki/Comestibles "Comestibles"):* [kelp frond](/wiki/Kelp_frond "Kelp frond")
* [eucalyptus leaf](/wiki/Eucalyptus_leaf "Eucalyptus leaf")
* [orange](/wiki/Orange "Orange")
* [pear](/wiki/Pear "Pear")
* [melon](/wiki/Melon "Melon")
* [sprig of wolfsbane](/wiki/Sprig_of_wolfsbane "Sprig of wolfsbane")
* [clove of garlic](/wiki/Clove_of_garlic "Clove of garlic")
* [slime mold](/wiki/Slime_mold "Slime mold")
* [banana](/wiki/Banana "Banana") (**treat** for any [apelike creature](/wiki/Apelike_creature "Apelike creature")) | starving   | **hungry** |
| [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         | *inedible* | *inedible* |
| harmful [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") unless resistant:* [acidic](/wiki/Acid "Acid")
* [poisonous](/wiki/Poison "Poison")
* [petrifying](/wiki/Petrify "Petrify") (including [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") eggs)
* old (≥50 turns, except lizards and lichens)
* [Riders](/wiki/Rider "Rider")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | *inedible* | *inedible* |

## Types of diet

### Omnivore

Most [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") monsters, including yourself initially, are [omnivores](/wiki/Omnivore "Omnivore"). This diet is essentially a combination of [carnivore](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore") and [herbivore](/wiki/Herbivore "Herbivore").

### Carnivore

[Carnivores](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore") are monsters that (when [tamed](/wiki/Tame "Tame")) prefer to eat meat. [Tripe](/wiki/Tripe "Tripe") and meat created with [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") are considered [treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat"). They will eat any safe [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") and [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg") that they find on the ground. They will eat "people food" such as [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration"), [pancakes](/wiki/Pancake "Pancake"), or [fortune cookies](/wiki/Fortune_cookie "Fortune cookie") if they are hungry and [vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian") food such as [fruit](/wiki/Fruit "Fruit") and [melons](/wiki/Melon "Melon") if starving. They will not eat [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") corpses such as [mold](/wiki/Mold "Mold") or [lichens](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen"), nor will they eat [tins](/wiki/Tin "Tin").

### Herbivore

[Herbivores](/wiki/Herbivore "Herbivore") are monsters that (when [tamed](/wiki/Tame "Tame")) prefer to eat vegetable matter such as [fruit](/wiki/Fruit "Fruit"), vegetables, [fungi](/wiki/Fungus "Fungus"), and other plants. [Apples](/wiki/Apple "Apple") and [carrots](/wiki/Carrot "Carrot") are considered [treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat"). They will eat safe [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") such as [lichens](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen"), [mold](/wiki/Mold "Mold"), [shriekers](/wiki/Shrieker "Shrieker"), [blobs](/wiki/Blob "Blob"), and [jellies](/wiki/Jelly "Jelly") if they find them lying on the ground. They will also eat [melons](/wiki/Melon "Melon"), [oranges](/wiki/Orange "Orange"), [pears](/wiki/Pear "Pear"), [wolfsbane](/wiki/Wolfsbane "Wolfsbane"), [garlic](/wiki/Garlic "Garlic"), [kelp fronds](/wiki/Kelp_frond "Kelp frond"), and so on, but only when hungry. If they are very hungry, they will eat some people food like [food rations](/wiki/Food_ration "Food ration"), [pancakes](/wiki/Pancake "Pancake"), and [lembas](/wiki/Lembas "Lembas"). They will never eat meat products, meaty corpses, [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg"), or [tins](/wiki/Tin "Tin").

### Metallivore

[Metallivores](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore") subsist on [metals](/wiki/Metal "Metal"), including not only metallic weapons and armor but also rings, amulets, and wands made of metal. In fact, a useful strategy is to [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a metallivore to gain [intrinsics](/wiki/Intrinsics "Intrinsics") by [eating jewelry](/wiki/Eating_jewelry "Eating jewelry"). They also eat tins of food, biting right through the tasty metal. Non-rustproof [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") objects are considered [treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat"). Unlike [xorns](/wiki/Xorn "Xorn") and [rock moles](/wiki/Rock_mole "Rock mole"), [rust monsters](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster") are restricted to the one metal that can rust, [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

Metallivorous monsters and players do not get hungry (unless they also eat meat or vegetables), but ring and amulet hunger still apply.

### Inediate

[Inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate") monsters do not need to eat any kind of food to stay alive, and cannot eat anything. Most monsters that are [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead"), [demonic](/wiki/Demonic "Demonic"), [angelic](/wiki/Angelic_being "Angelic being"), or otherwise magical in nature are inediate.

### Special cases

Several monsters have unique diets.

- b [Gelatinous cubes](/wiki/Gelatinous_cube "Gelatinous cube") eat [wood](/wiki/Wood "Wood"), [leather](/wiki/Leather "Leather"), and [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth"), and engulf most everything else.
- h [Mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") eat the brains out of living monsters.
- U [Umber hulks](/wiki/Umber_hulk "Umber hulk") can chew through [solid rock](/wiki/Solid_rock "Solid rock"), which gives them nutrition. They cannot, however, eat items made of rock ([mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral"), as it is called in-game).
- Z [Ghouls](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul") eat only [old](/wiki/Food_poisoning "Food poisoning") corpses.

None of these monsters need to eat to stay alive.

### Internals

Internally, the diet of a monster type is indicated by the flags M1\_CARNIVORE and M1\_HERBIVORE; both flags are set for an omnivore, and neither is set for inediates. The M1\_METALLIVORE flag denotes a metallivore. Interestingly, a monster with M1\_METALLIVORE but not M1\_CARNIVORE or M1\_HERBIVORE is considered inediate for in-game purposes.

## Variants

### SlashTHEM

[SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") features [lithivorous](/wiki/Lithivore "Lithivore") monsters, which are capable of eating not only rocks and gems, but also items made of [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral"), [bone](/wiki/Bone "Bone"), [gemstone](/wiki/Gemstone "Gemstone"), or [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass"). Lithic objects are considered [treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat") for lithivores. [Polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a lithivore allows the player to gain [intrinsics](/wiki/Intrinsics "Intrinsics") by [eating jewelry](/wiki/Eating_jewelry "Eating jewelry").

## See also

- [Comestibles](/wiki/Comestible "Comestible")
- [Nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")
- [Treats](/wiki/Treat "Treat")
- [Domestic animals](/wiki/Domestic_animal "Domestic animal")

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [Source:edog.h#line10](/wiki/Source:Edog.h#line10 "Source:Edog.h") for definition of food grades
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [Source:dog.c#dogfood](/wiki/Source:Dog.c#dogfood "Source:Dog.c") for food classification
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [dogmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 170](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dogmove.c#line170 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dogmove.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [dogmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 427](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dogmove.c#line427 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dogmove.c")
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [dog.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 780](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dog.c#line780 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dog.c")
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [dogmove.c, line 297](/wiki/Source:Dogmove.c#line297 "Source:Dogmove.c") and [dogmove.c, line 675](/wiki/Source:Dogmove.c#line675 "Source:Dogmove.c")
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [dogmove.c, line 675](/wiki/Source:Dogmove.c#line675 "Source:Dogmove.c") [dog.c, line 780](/wiki/Source:Dog.c#line780 "Source:Dog.c"), [dothrow.c, line 1382](/wiki/Source:Dothrow.c#line1382 "Source:Dothrow.c")
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [dogmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 297](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dogmove.c#line297 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dogmove.c")
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [dog.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 808](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dog.c#line808 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dog.c")
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [dogmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 377](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dogmove.c#line377 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dogmove.c")
11. [↑](#cite_ref-11) [Source:dog.c#dogfood](/wiki/Source:Dog.c#dogfood "Source:Dog.c") technically reclassifies some of it as ACCFOOD when starving.
12. [↑](#cite_ref-12) [dogmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 377](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dogmove.c#line377 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dogmove.c")
13. [↑](#cite_ref-13) [dothrow.c, line 1383](/wiki/Source:Dothrow.c#line1383 "Source:Dothrow.c") (see also definition of befriend\_with\_obj at [mondata.h, line 190](/wiki/Source:Mondata.h#line190 "Source:Mondata.h"))
14. [↑](#cite_ref-14) [dog.c, line 756](/wiki/Source:Dog.c#line756 "Source:Dog.c"): "worst case, at least it'll be peaceful" (see also [dogfood](/wiki/Source:Dog.c#dogfood "Source:Dog.c") above)

[![This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/b/b0/Nh343-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Diet

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In NetHack, the diet of a monster describes which types of things it will eat.

Every monster, including yourself, is restricted to eating only certain materials. Solid foods that are edible to your starting character are generally classified as comestibles, but if you polymorph into a different type of monster, you may find yourself snacking on such things as shirts or wands. Further, many types of monsters have strong innate preferences with regard to meats and vegetable matter.

Contents

  • 1 Your diet
  • 2 Pets
  • 3 Types of diet
    • 3.1 Omnivore
    • 3.2 Carnivore
    • 3.3 Herbivore
    • 3.4 Metallivore
    • 3.5 Inediate
    • 3.6 Special cases
    • 3.7 Internals
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SlashTHEM
  • 5 See also
  • 6 References

Your diet

You, as a monster endowed with free will, are restricted only by your physical capacity to consume. Still, your diet is determined by what you are. Most character types are omnivores, although monks are effectively herbivores, suffering an alignment penalty for eating non-vegetarian food. Being a carnivore or herbivore (or even inediate) does not restrict your ability to eat, but does make the respective food types more delicious.

You are the only creature that can open a tin of food. You can also quaff any form of liquid nourishment, provided you are capable of drinking. When polymorphed into a new type of monster, you can eat whatever that monster type can eat, in addition to the usual comestibles. Note, however, that being capable of eating something does not mean that you should eat it; eating a dead cockatrice by mistake has ended many a game, and eating your own race carries the penalties of cannibalism.

Three conducts tracked by the game entail voluntarily restricting your diet: vegetarian, vegan, and foodless.

Pets

See also Pet#Pet diets

Most types of monsters eat only when tame, i.e., your pets; the exceptions are metallivores and other unique diets, which largely avoid safe comestibles. A pet encountering something it is capable of eating will decide whether to eat it according to its dietary preference and its degree of hunger, with due care to avoid harmful meals. A pet cat, for example, will eat a banana only when starving. Diet also determines which foods will tame a domestic animal and which foods a pet considers a treat. Thus it is helpful to be aware of the diets of your pets or potential pets you want to tame (that pony wants an apple, not a yucky tripe ration!), besides watching out for monsters that might go after your treasures (a rock mole ate my gold stash!).

Most pets must continually eat to stave off starvation. Besides a normal state of contentment, a pet has two degrees of hunger. Hungry is what a stethoscope and #chatting indicate. Starving means the pet "is confused from hunger" or "you feel worried about" it, and implies the pet's maximum hit points are reduced to 25%. Beyond that, it will cease to be your pet, either dying or, if on another level, becoming hostile.

Pets react differently to various foods according to how appealing they find it. From best to worst, the grades of food are as follows.[1][2]

Food grade Internal name Effect
treat DOGFOOD A delicious treat suitable for training.[3] Will make pets follow more closely.[4]. Pets will "catch" it, which is purely cosmetic.[5]
good CADAVER Will be eaten happily.[6]
hungry ACCFOOD Will be eaten if hungry,[7] but the pet will seek it out only if starving.[8] (Try throwing the food at the pet.) The minimum food grade needed for taming.[9] The worst quality food that will to suppress the message "Foo moves only reluctantly."[10]
starving MANFOOD (ACCFOOD when starving) Will be eaten only if starving.[11] Otherwise, the pet wants to apport the food.[12]
inedible MANFOOD, APPORT, POISON, UNDEF, TABU Will be left untouched even while the poor creature starves to death.

Untame domestic animals (dogs, cats, and horses) will not eat spontaneously but will react favorably to food you throw at them (apart from eggs, melons, and cream pies that hit their target and splat 99% of the time). If the food is considered grade "hungry" or better, the animal will eat it and become tame; this is an easy way to acquire pets. Any other comestible will not be eaten but will pacify the animal and remove any fear effects, unless the animal is a domestic u. Only veggy food will pacify domestic horses if not eaten; these items are listed in the "starving herbivores" section of the table below. [13][14]

Carnivores and herbivores evaluate food in very different ways, tabulated below. The obvious trend to bear in mind is that carnivores prefer meats and herbivores prefer vegetable matter. Omnivores generally apply the more favorable grade out of both.

Food Carnivores Herbivores
tripe ration, or meat ring/stick/ball/chunk treat inedible
safe egg (do not throw!) good inedible
safe corpse, non-vegan good inedible
safe corpse, vegan inedible good
apple, carrot starving treat
people food:
  • lump of royal jelly
  • cream pie (do not throw!)
  • candy bar
  • fortune cookie
  • pancake
  • lembas wafer
  • food/cram/K-/C-ration
 hungry starving
other vegan comestibles:
  • kelp frond
  • eucalyptus leaf
  • orange
  • pear
  • melon
  • sprig of wolfsbane
  • clove of garlic
  • slime mold
  • banana (treat for any apelike creature)
 starving hungry
tin inedible inedible
harmful corpse unless resistant:
  • acidic
  • poisonous
  • petrifying (including cockatrice eggs)
  • old (≥50 turns, except lizards and lichens)
  • Riders
 inedible inedible

Types of diet

Omnivore

Most humanoid monsters, including yourself initially, are omnivores. This diet is essentially a combination of carnivore and herbivore.

Carnivore

Carnivores are monsters that (when tamed) prefer to eat meat. Tripe and meat created with stone to flesh are considered treats. They will eat any safe corpses and eggs that they find on the ground. They will eat "people food" such as food rations, pancakes, or fortune cookies if they are hungry and vegetarian food such as fruit and melons if starving. They will not eat vegan corpses such as mold or lichens, nor will they eat tins.

Herbivore

Herbivores are monsters that (when tamed) prefer to eat vegetable matter such as fruit, vegetables, fungi, and other plants. Apples and carrots are considered treats. They will eat safe vegan corpses such as lichens, mold, shriekers, blobs, and jellies if they find them lying on the ground. They will also eat melons, oranges, pears, wolfsbane, garlic, kelp fronds, and so on, but only when hungry. If they are very hungry, they will eat some people food like food rations, pancakes, and lembas. They will never eat meat products, meaty corpses, eggs, or tins.

Metallivore

Metallivores subsist on metals, including not only metallic weapons and armor but also rings, amulets, and wands made of metal. In fact, a useful strategy is to polymorph into a metallivore to gain intrinsics by eating jewelry. They also eat tins of food, biting right through the tasty metal. Non-rustproof iron objects are considered treats. Unlike xorns and rock moles, rust monsters are restricted to the one metal that can rust, iron.

Metallivorous monsters and players do not get hungry (unless they also eat meat or vegetables), but ring and amulet hunger still apply.

Inediate

Inediate monsters do not need to eat any kind of food to stay alive, and cannot eat anything. Most monsters that are undead, demonic, angelic, or otherwise magical in nature are inediate.

Special cases

Several monsters have unique diets.

  • b Gelatinous cubes eat wood, leather, and cloth, and engulf most everything else.
  • h Mind flayers eat the brains out of living monsters.
  • U Umber hulks can chew through solid rock, which gives them nutrition. They cannot, however, eat items made of rock (mineral, as it is called in-game).
  • Z Ghouls eat only old corpses.

None of these monsters need to eat to stay alive.

Internals

Internally, the diet of a monster type is indicated by the flags M1_CARNIVORE and M1_HERBIVORE; both flags are set for an omnivore, and neither is set for inediates. The M1_METALLIVORE flag denotes a metallivore. Interestingly, a monster with M1_METALLIVORE but not M1_CARNIVORE or M1_HERBIVORE is considered inediate for in-game purposes.

Variants

SlashTHEM

SlashTHEM features lithivorous monsters, which are capable of eating not only rocks and gems, but also items made of mineral, bone, gemstone, or glass. Lithic objects are considered treats for lithivores. Polymorphing into a lithivore allows the player to gain intrinsics by eating jewelry.

See also

  • Comestibles
  • Nutrition
  • Treats
  • Domestic animals

rawPage:
In ''[[NetHack]]'', the '''diet''' of a monster describes which types of things it will eat. 

Every monster, including yourself, is restricted to eating only certain [[material]]s. Solid foods that are edible to your starting character are generally classified as [[comestible]]s, but if you [[polymorph]] into a different type of monster, you may find yourself snacking on such things as shirts or wands. Further, many types of monsters have strong innate preferences with regard to meats and vegetable matter. 

==Your diet==
You, as a monster endowed with free will, are restricted only by your physical capacity to consume. Still, your diet is determined by what you are. Most character types are omnivores, although [[monk]]s are effectively herbivores, suffering an alignment penalty for eating non-vegetarian food. Being a carnivore or herbivore (or even inediate) does not restrict your ability to eat, but does make the respective food types more delicious. 

You are the only creature that can open a [[tin]] of food. You can also quaff any form of [[Foodless#Restoring nutrition|liquid nourishment]], provided you are capable of drinking. When [[polymorph]]ed into a new type of monster, you can eat whatever that monster type can eat, in addition to the usual [[comestibles]]. Note, however, that being ''capable'' of eating something does not mean that you ''should'' eat it; eating a dead [[cockatrice]] by mistake has ended many a game, and eating your own race carries the penalties of [[cannibalism]]. 

Three [[conducts]] tracked by the game entail ''voluntarily'' restricting your diet: vegetarian, vegan, and [[foodless]]. 

==Pets==
:''See also [[Pet#Pet diets]]''
Most types of monsters eat only when [[tameness|tame]], i.e., your [[pet]]s; the exceptions are metallivores and other unique diets, which largely avoid safe comestibles. A pet encountering something it is capable of eating will decide whether to eat it according to its dietary preference and its degree of [[nutrition|hunger]], with due care to avoid harmful meals. A pet [[cat]], for example, will eat a banana only when starving. Diet also determines which foods will tame a [[domestic animal]] and which foods a pet considers a [[treat]]. Thus it is helpful to be aware of the diets of your [[pet]]s or potential pets you want to [[tame]] (that pony wants an apple, not a yucky tripe ration!), besides watching out for monsters that might go after your treasures (a rock mole ate my gold stash!). 

Most [[pet]]s must continually eat to stave off [[Nutrition#Nutrition_and_pets|starvation]]. Besides a normal state of contentment, a pet has two degrees of hunger. ''Hungry'' is what a [[stethoscope]] and #[[chat]]ting indicate. ''Starving'' means the pet "is confused from hunger" or "you feel worried about" it, and implies the pet's maximum hit points are reduced to 25%. Beyond that, it will cease to be your pet, either dying or, if on another level, becoming [[tameness|hostile]]. 

Pets react differently to various [[food]]s according to how appealing they find it. From best to worst, the grades of food are as follows.<ref>[[Source:edog.h#line10]] for definition of food grades</ref><ref>[[Source:dog.c#dogfood]] for food classification</ref>

{|class="prettytable"
!Food grade
!Internal name
!Effect
|-
|'''treat'''
|DOGFOOD
|A delicious [[treat]] suitable for [[apport|training]].{{refsrc|dogmove.c|170}} Will make pets follow more closely.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|427}}. Pets will "catch" it, which is purely cosmetic.{{refsrc|dog.c|780}}
|-
|'''good'''
|CADAVER
|Will be eaten happily.<ref>{{sourcecode|dogmove.c|297}} and {{sourcecode|dogmove.c|675}}</ref>
|-
|'''hungry'''
|ACCFOOD
|Will be eaten if hungry,<ref>{{sourcecode|dogmove.c|675}} {{sourcecode|dog.c|780}}, {{sourcecode|dothrow.c|1382}}</ref> but the pet will seek it out only if starving.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|297}} (Try throwing the food at the pet.) The minimum food grade needed for taming.{{refsrc|dog.c|808}} The worst quality food that will to suppress the message "[[Foo]] moves only reluctantly."{{refsrc|dogmove.c|377}}

|starving
|MANFOOD (ACCFOOD when starving)
|Will be eaten only if starving.<ref>[[Source:dog.c#dogfood]] technically reclassifies some of it as ACCFOOD when starving.</ref> Otherwise, the pet wants to apport the food.{{refsrc|dogmove.c|377}}
|-
|''inedible''
|MANFOOD, APPORT, POISON, UNDEF, TABU<!--Yes, MANFOOD features twice because dogfood reclassifies only some items when starving.-->
|Will be left untouched even while the poor creature starves to death.
|}

Untame [[domestic animal]]s (dogs, cats, and horses) will not eat spontaneously but will react favorably to food you throw at them (apart from eggs, melons, and cream pies that hit their target and splat 99% of the time). If the food is considered grade "hungry" or better, the animal will eat it and become [[tame]]; this is an easy way to [[Pet#New_pets|acquire pets]]. Any other [[comestible]] will not be eaten but will [[peaceful|pacify]] the animal and remove any [[fear]] effects, unless the animal is a domestic {{monsym|pony}}. Only veggy food will pacify domestic horses if not eaten; these items are listed in the "starving herbivores" section of the table below. <ref>{{sourcecode|dothrow.c|1383}} (see also definition of befriend_with_obj at {{sourcecode|mondata.h|190}})</ref><ref>{{sourcecode|dog.c|756}}: "worst case, at least it'll be peaceful" (see also {{function|dog.c|dogfood|x}} above)</ref> 

Carnivores and herbivores evaluate food in very different ways, tabulated below. The obvious trend to bear in mind is that carnivores prefer meats and herbivores prefer vegetable matter. Omnivores generally apply the more favorable grade out of both.

== Types of diet ==

=== Omnivore ===

Most [[humanoid]] monsters, including yourself initially, are [[omnivore]]s. This diet is essentially a combination of [[carnivore]] and [[herbivore]]. 

=== Carnivore ===

[[Carnivore]]s are monsters that (when [[tame]]d) prefer to eat meat. [[Tripe]] and meat created with [[stone to flesh]] are considered [[treat]]s. They will eat any safe [[corpse]]s and [[egg]]s that they find on the ground. They will eat "people food" such as [[food ration]]s, [[pancake]]s, or [[fortune cookie]]s if they are hungry and [[vegetarian]] food such as [[fruit]] and [[melon]]s if starving. They will not eat [[vegan]] corpses such as [[mold]] or [[lichen]]s, nor will they eat [[tin]]s.

=== Herbivore ===

[[Herbivore]]s are monsters that (when [[tame]]d) prefer to eat vegetable matter such as [[fruit]], vegetables, [[fungus|fungi]], and other plants. [[Apple]]s and [[carrot]]s are considered [[treat]]s. They will eat safe [[vegan]] [[corpse]]s such as [[lichen]]s, [[mold]], [[shrieker]]s, [[blob]]s, and [[jelly|jellies]] if they find them lying on the ground. They will also eat [[melon]]s, [[orange]]s, [[pear]]s, [[wolfsbane]], [[garlic]], [[kelp frond]]s, and so on, but only when hungry. If they are very hungry, they will eat some people food like [[food ration]]s, [[pancake]]s, and [[lembas]]. They will never eat meat products, meaty corpses, [[egg]]s, or [[tin]]s.

=== Metallivore ===

[[Metallivore]]s subsist on [[metal]]s, including not only metallic weapons and armor but also rings, amulets, and wands made of metal. In fact, a useful strategy is to [[polymorph]] into a metallivore to gain [[intrinsics]] by [[eating jewelry]]. They also eat tins of food, biting right through the tasty metal. Non-rustproof [[iron]] objects are considered [[treat]]s. Unlike [[xorn]]s and [[rock mole]]s, [[rust monster]]s are restricted to the one metal that can rust, [[iron]].

Metallivorous monsters and players do not get hungry (unless they also eat meat or vegetables), but ring and amulet hunger still apply.

=== Inediate ===

[[Inediate]] monsters do not need to eat any kind of food to stay alive, and cannot eat anything. Most monsters that are [[undead]], [[demonic]], [[Angelic being|angelic]], or otherwise magical in nature are inediate. 

=== Special cases ===
Several monsters have unique diets.
* {{monsymlink|Gelatinous cube}}s eat [[wood]], [[leather]], and [[cloth]], and engulf most everything else.
* {{monsymlink|Mind flayer}}s eat the brains out of living monsters.
* {{monsymlink|Umber hulk}}s can chew through [[solid rock]], which gives them nutrition.  They cannot, however, eat items made of rock ([[mineral]], as it is called in-game).
* {{monsymlink|Ghoul}}s eat only [[Food poisoning|old]] corpses.

None of these monsters need to eat to stay alive.

=== Internals ===
Internally, the diet of a monster type is indicated by the flags M1_CARNIVORE and M1_HERBIVORE; both flags are set for an omnivore, and neither is set for inediates. The M1_METALLIVORE flag denotes a metallivore. Interestingly, a monster with M1_METALLIVORE but not M1_CARNIVORE or M1_HERBIVORE is considered inediate for in-game purposes.

==Variants==
===SlashTHEM===
[[SlashTHEM]] features [[lithivore|lithivorous]] monsters, which are capable of eating not only rocks and gems, but also items made of [[mineral]], [[bone]], [[gemstone]], or [[glass]]. Lithic objects are considered [[treat]]s for lithivores. [[Polymorph]]ing into a lithivore allows the player to gain [[intrinsics]] by [[eating jewelry]].
